title: 111_hr291
content: The Act may be cited as the "Unemployment Supplemental Assistance Act" and includes an increase in unemployment compensation benefits. Any State can enter into an agreement with the Secretary of Labor to participate in additional compensation payments under the Unemployment Supplemental Assistance Act. States can terminate the agreement with 30 days' notice. The agreement ensures that individuals receive regular compensation as per State law. The State law can be modified to increase regular compensation by $50 per week. Additional compensation can be paid at the same time as regular compensation or separately on a weekly basis. An agreement under this section cannot reduce benefits. An agreement under this section will not apply if the method for calculating regular compensation in a State is changed in a way that would result in lower benefits than what would have been paid under the original State law. Payments to States will be made in full reimbursement. Payments to States under this section will be made in full reimbursement, covering additional compensation and administrative expenses incurred by the State. The payment terms will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will determine the reimbursement amounts for each State monthly, adjusting for any over or underestimations from prior months. The Secretary will certify payments to the Treasury for each State under this section. The Secretary will determine reimbursement amounts for each State monthly, certifying payments to the Treasury. Sums payable to States under this section are appropriated from the Treasury's general fund without fiscal year limitation. Agreements under this section apply to unemployment weeks starting after the agreement date and ending before January 1, 2010, with a transition rule for individuals entitled to regular compensation as of January 1, 2010. The State law allows for additional compensation to be paid to eligible individuals for weeks beginning before June 30, 2010. Fraud and overpayment rules from the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008 apply to this additional compensation. Each agreement under this section includes provisions for applying the purposes of the preceding provisions to unemployment benefits as if they were regular compensation. Additional compensation is not payable for unemployment benefits after a specified date, except for eligible individuals. Additional compensation is not payable for unemployment benefits after a specified date, except for eligible individuals. Definitions for terms related to compensation and unemployment benefits are provided under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The text chunk discusses emergency unemployment compensation under the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008, and references extended and regular unemployment benefits provided by states under agreements with the Secretary.
